text: Nice beer with loads of foam! Beautiful colour and body, but somewhat bland aroma. Taste is somewhat bland too, with some touches of herb (koriander?). It is easy on the palate and good beer to drink on the terrace, but not a showjumper.

Red orange robe.
Nose of malt caramel yeast and a bit of potted orange
Light and watery body, no bubbles.
Palate close to nose, but no finish at all, quite deceived by that, was expecting a bit more on the bitterness side.
Very smooth and balanced ESB with an apparent malty sweetness topped with subtle hopping and a long finish.
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2017 From a bomber into a snifter. Clear copper brown color with light brown head. Biscuit, caramel, bread, a bit of grass. Light body, slightly sweet.

Color ámbar, translúcido, con capa de espuma de un blanco amarillento de tres dedos de grosor (buena retención). Carbonatación media tirando a alta (más sutil en boca). Textura acuosa. Aroma a malta caramelizada, malta tostada, frutos secos, con toque floral. Sabor dulce, donde la malta tostada, el caramelo, los frutos secos y el lúpulo se dan la mano como si nada hubiera pasado. Marcado carácter floral de nuevo, al igual que en aroma, así como cierto recuerdo o reminiscencia a pan tanto en nariz como en boca. El final podría calificarlo como de mínimo amargor pero ni eso diré, más bien dulce (sin ser empalagoso, nadie vaya a pensar mal). En boca, entre trago y trago, quedan caramelo y frutos secos. Una maravilla.

(Draught at Beer Temple, Amsterdam, 25 Feb 2017) Amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with notes of caramel, treacle-toffee and orange peel. Malty, slightly fruity taste with caramel, toffee, orange peel, dried apricots and a balanced bitterness. Medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Tasty and well balanced. Nice one.
Ill Birrificio bottle(2-Apr-17)Toffee light ash smoke aroma. Cloudy dark amber, good cream head and spider lacing. Toffee herbal flavour. Tangy fruit herbal finish and toffee malt aftertaste.

Slight hop malt aroma. Dark brown colour great head and lacing. Caramel malt hop flavour. Smooth lingering palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Beerlovers, tasted at Zil Vernes Tasting. Amber color with medium off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, earthy hops. Taste, caramel, malt, earthy hops, light fruitiness in finish. Very good.
Geiles Bitter. Earthy fruity mit Kupferung. So soll das Pub Ale munden...Loveo ;)... Schwerer Style...cooles Ergebnis. 15cl/3,75. BEER TEMPLE Amsterdam. FAT.

22oz bottle on 4th Feb 2017 in my daughters new place in Laguna Niguel. Really enjoyed this beer, good amber colour, full, lasting head. Malty front, center and finish, caramel sweetness tempered (just) by a slightly bitter hop presence.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber with small beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is english yeast and toasted malt. Medium body, toast, caramel, light dry finish, good.
Bottle. Amber brown with very thin head. Aroma of caramel, toasted malts and a hint of sweetness. Medium body, moderate sweetness, toasted malt sweetness, with a slight bitter hop finish.

From bottle in English pint glass. Pours rusty bronze and clear with billowing, lively head. Mild malt aroma that transformed nicely upon warming as did the taste with some caramel sweetness in the finish without much bitterness.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.
Little aroma. Too little malt sweetness and too much hop bitterness. Medium Amber color with average head.
Starts with a caramel and sweet notes, followed by a nice bitter aroma, very well balanced and easy going beer.

coppery red slightly turbid medium intensity. Regular crown middle bubble and sand color with good permanence leaving as cobweb lace. Aromas of medium intensity roasted malt, caramel and herbal hops. The palate is light-bodied with little input carbonation bitter and sweet to creamy caramel, sweet and fruity rebound step. slightly metallic and fruity, dry hoppy little lasting background. Little complexity, perfect execution style.

Tough one to call... love the style, but this bucks tradition. Pours a clear amber-brown of the style. Aroma is unexpected with caramel bread being slightly overwhelmed by a hoppy funk. Flavor is similar though much better. Again some unwanted hop bitter mingling with an otherwise-delicious sweet malt. Finish is fairly dry and clean.

Sampler at AEON Liquor. Huge caramel, malt-forward nose with bread, raisin toasted nuts. Very malt-forward with some toasted bitterness. Not too sweet, with dry finish. Nice enough for a style Im not crazy about.

On tap at Codys Irish Pub, Essex Junction, VT.
This was poured into a pint glass.
The appearance was a hazy burnt orange to toasty amber color with a thin bar pours white head that slides away.
The aroma has a big English sweet fruity esters with a smooth aromatic earthy malt and some grassy hops coming together nicely.
The flavor brings it together, the malty sweetness and the grassy hops. Smooth and swerves into the aftertaste with a quick crisp finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a great sessionability about. Low carbonation. Smooth, almost sticky.
Overall, as an ESB, this is a top notch one by style, as it presents very clean flavors. Id have again with some fish n chips.
Bottle in wine glass. A bold ESB. Never had a beer before with such a straightforward caramel profile. Great experience, but a bit too much to be highly enjoyable imo.

From the 650 ml. bottle that was bottled on 07/01/2016. Attractive red amber pour with a long lasting cream colored head that leaves a lot of lacing. The aroma seems to bring out a cocoa and caramel character with a cardboard box kind of mustiness. Low to no hop profile. The body is medium to bold. I still get that cocoa sweetness and toasted cracker character in the taste with a mild bitter finish.

Aroma:

Slight/medium aroma of malts, caramel, bread and hops.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque dark orange/brown beer with a slight/medium off-white/beige head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts slightly/medium sweet with malts and caramel; ends slightly dry with bread and hops.

Overall:

This beer is rather intense and balanced, but lacks complexity. Easy to drink, but that is about anything to it.
Pours a hazy Amber color. Some sweet malty aromas. Taste is caramel, bread and some stone fruit. A very tasty esb

On tap at brewpub. A clear orange hued amber with a short lived white head. Aroma is caramel, fruits, cherry. Flavor is caramel, toast, cherry. Finish is some citrus, caramel, toast. Lingering cherry and caramel. Medium body, average carbonation.

Dark amber pour with large off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, fruits, hops and pine. Taste of caramel malts, slightly fruity, pine, grapefruit and hops. Medium bodied, higher carbonation, crisp mouthfeel. Perfectly balanced. An amazing example of this beer style!

Bottle, bottled 01.30 (from beergium). Pours amber-copper with beige head. The head stays for some time. Aroma is sweet, caramel, fruits, citrus, floral notes. Flavor is sweet and bitter, caramel, fruits, malt, citrus, toffee, slight alcohol. Finish is toffee bitter. Body is bit watery, carbonation is on the high side. Overall: good, but would like to try fresher version.
Pours a dark amber color with a foamy white head. Notes of dark fruits, caramel, toasted bread, and fresh air. Really nice, well balanced.

On tap at Alesmith brewpub. Ruby red. Slightly fruity malty aroma. Sweet British style esb in the vein of Fullers. Long lasting flavor of dry, malty, nutty goodness. A good pub style brew. Really nice on tap.
Pours a nice hazy golden orange color. Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops. Flavor starts malty and the hops kick in, nice crisp bitter finish.

Bottle from Erzbierschof Zurich. A typical medium-ABV Alesmith: Nutty, pines, some caramel, rather malt-dominated, and incredibly drinkable! Doesnt go in any particular style direction as other beers, hardly recognizable as an ESB. Not overly complex, but otherwise this beer does many things right: Texture, carbonation, balance, palate...

UPDATED: APR 11, 2016 Draft at Bru Craft. Poured a hazy dark ruby with off-white foam that left nice splashes of lace. Medium-dark caramel bready flavors. Dark citrus elements as well. Pomegranate. Honey wheat bread. Plums and prunes. Clove studded oranges. Purple passionfruit. Black currants. Black cherries. Black pepper. Much more shinny than flat. A dark juicy ESB.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2016 En palancas...la bomber. Aroma para mi gusto demasiado caramelo, casi chocolate para el estilo con un fondo de buen lúpulo fresco, hierba y frutal. De dulce un pelin subida para mi gusto. Punto mild.Aún así una birra cojonuda. Bien hecha.

Où, Quand, Comment : 
Bouteille, dégustée le 8/22/2013. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : ambrée-orangée foncée. 
Apparence : semi-voilée. 


Arôme :  

Caramel, houblon herbeux et légèrement fruité (agrumes) et aux notes épicées. 


Goût :  
Entrée de bouche : Léger goût fruité (agrumes) et épicé (poivre). 
Une dominante de grains de malt sucrés et de caramel doux est présente avec une légère amertume de houblon herbeux, légèrement fruité (zeste dagrumes) et aux notes florales et terreuses.


En bouche :  

Corps : moyen.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : légèrement huileuse.
Finale : moyenne et aux notes sèches, composée dune légère amertume de houblon herbeux aux notes florales et épicées ainsi que quelques notes fruitées et maltées.

Enorme ejemplar en su especie. Una ESB ambarina, de cuerpo sedoso y carácter tostado. Una rica combinación de maltas y lúpulo británicos que nos llevan desde notas dulces y tostadas a pan, frutas maduras, dátiles, pasas hasta un final floral ligeramente amargo que hace genial el trato.
This beer is available at the new Wexford Pub at Whole foods. dark amber color and a fair frothy head with a faint hops fragrance. Body is a little thin but plenty of malts.

Clear copper color with medium beige head. Aroma is sweet and bready, with caramel, biscuit, sugar syrup and melon. Taste has honey, bread, dough, caramel, light milk chocolate and dark fruits. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, ok bold sweet bitter

Mahogany body with a creamy head.
Malty aroma and flavour, with notes of hops and dried fruit. Lightly sweet taste with medium bitterness.
Medium body with soft mouthfeel and average carbonation.

Simple and tasty beer. Very drinkable.

Aroma: caramel, grass, bread, 
Appearance: clear amber with an off-white head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, 

Tasty
Pours a hazy coppery brown with a beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasty, hints of fruit and hops. Taste is medium sweet.
Bottle a amber colored beer with a white head aroma malts citrus fruits spicy some yeast and hops flavor malts citrus fruits pineapple some grapefruits spicy and bitter hops

Pours bronze/brown with an off white head. The aroma has toasty malt, English yeast, dry crackers and some bright hop notes. It had a medium body with restrained carbonation. The taste starts with mild toasted malt, English fruitiness, mild earthy yeast, nuts and bread. The finish is short and clean. Excellent ESB.
Deep mahogany, light tan head. Light biscuit and caramel. Light bitterness. Biscuity, caramel sweetness. Light body, slightly chewy. Good.

Flaske 1,66 fl.oz. på Bishops Arms, Kiruna 2 Jun 15. Mørk gyldenbrun. Middels høyt luftig skum med spotlacing. Rik fruktig aroma med malt i bunnen. Smaken fersken - fortsatt med preg av malt. Uklar siste kvelling.

Bottle, pours a clear amber body with a tan head. Aroma of malts, caramel, biscuit/dough, brown sugar, and light prune/raisin. Taste is similar with a light hop note; nice subtle complexity for this style.Slightly sweet finish with a somewhat lingering bitterness.
Smell of caramel, malts. Cloudy brown colour, beige head. Aroma of hops, caramel, malt. Medium bitter, with some sweetness involved. Lively but soft carbon, slightly oily palate. Medium to rich body.

Backlog rating. Keg at BD Shoreditch, London. It p[ours a clear copper color with medium beige head. Aroma is sweet and bready, with caramel, biscuit, sugar syrup and melon. Taste has honey, bread, dough, caramel, light milk chocolate and dark fruits. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, ok bold sweet bitter
Bue en bouteille. Couleur ambré brun. Beau maltage, rondeur et corpulence. Et belle amertume simple. Finale plus complexe sur la vanille ou le fruit noir.

Bottle. Turners, Sheffield. Clear copper colour. Thin, blotchy, fresh ginger coloured head. Nose has cake fruit malts. Stewed, dark fruit. Syrupy hop. Taste is brown sugar sweet. Gentle bitterness forms. Soft, and fairly full mouthfeel. Finishes light, fruity bitter, with a syrupy sweet longer. Ok.

Small taster showing dark brown. 

The nose shows moderately intense clean malts and tea. 

The palate is light bodied and well carbonated with a grainy maltiness and tea-like astringency on the finish.

Muted caramel and pine aroma, in equal proportions. Clear rust, thin yellow head. Nice malt and caramel interplay, fairly mild. Finishes a little woody. Medium to full body, easy carbonation. Well balanced, sessionable.

Mahogany toffee pour with a soapy off white head.
Aroma is burnt toast, toffee and woody hop.
Flavour is nice fruit and nut front end, bready caramel/toffee. Not overly sweet though. Light woody and slight resinous finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber->English pint. Amber with thick lite beige head. A: subtle caramel malt, biscuit, lite hops. T: caramel malt, noble hops, vanilla. Bittersweet. Very drinkable.

Excellent, of course. Nice malty backbone with just the right amount of hop bitterness, done in the English style and punched up a little with an American kick but not overdone. As with their other standards, really well balanced, excellent mouthfeel, quality ingredients.
Good looking beer has a beautiful amber color and pours with a thick creamy head. It has a mild aroma. It has a really nice smokey malt flavor and is easy to swallow all together
Pours orange to brown with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, honey, bitterness and fruits, flavor is bitter with chocolate, honey, bread, fruits, medium bodied.
A terrific Americanized version of the English pub ESB. Lots of toffee, caramel and toast, with a hastening hop presence and some good warming notes.

Bottle. Lovely copper pour with a medium, foamy tan head. Lots of caramel, sweet malt, dark bready notes, light grassy hops, tea leaves and toffee. Taste is toasted malt, sweet malt, grains, caramel, light grass, tea leaves and dark bread. Body is medium and slightly chewy with a moderate, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more sweet malt, big caramel, toasted grains, dark bread and light grassy hops. Nice!

22 oz. bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a tight off white head that leaves a wispy film and collar. Aroma is English malt subtle spice caramel. Taste is spice bitterness and caramel malts nuttiness. Palate is clean thin slightly dry.
From 6floz bomber..one of the best American ESBs i have tried. Lovely malty taste and smell.

Bottle from Portage Lakes Brewing. Poured into a tulip. Moderate amber color with ample head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, wheat bread, biscuit. The flavor is biscuit, caramel, toffee, and some slight bittering hops. Well balanced. Medium body. Caramel finish.
Bottle. Deep amber with two finger head. Sweet caramel and toffee. Bready with a light bitter hoppiness. Excellent flavor, but mild at the same time.

Bue en bouteille de 66cl à la brasserie, 
Couleur ambrée, mousse blanche et pas deffervescence.
Nez sur le houblon anglais.
En bouche goût de banane et de pêche. Mais trop léger.

(En fût à la brasserie): Une tarte aux pommes bien caramélisée constitue lessentiel des arômes et du goût de la Anvil. Une certaine minéralité combinée aux houblons terreux complètent cette distinctive ESB.

Taster at the brewery. Amber copper color with small white head. Aroma is toffee, caramel, dark bread crust. Taste is richer than youd expect from an ESB. Dark bread crust, caramel, a bit vanilla, moderately bitter finish. Super smooth Pub Ale mouthfeel. Probably the best ESB Ive ever had.

From bomber, possibly outdated. Poured with an extremely thick, cloud-like head and deep orange-amber body. Aroma is very sweet caramel/molasses with vanilla and some breadiness. Flavor is biscuity, subtly bitter with a pale sweetness overriding it. Carbonation very high (seeing as it is bottle-conditioned, this may be an old batch). Albeit not very fresh, still very drinkable.

Bottle poured an amber hue with large foamy lasting white head. Light to moderate sweet malt and bread aromas. Initial flavor is light to moderate sweet w/a light to moderate bitter finish. Tastes are caramel, toast and hay. Medium bodied.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Rich brown color. Full malt flavor, some nuts as well. Very light roasted character. Dry, woody flavor with aome rye bread. Rich, full palate.
Bottle, 650 ml from Svijet Piva, Zagreb. Shared with Miro and Kova. Pours brown with an off white head. Caramel malty, toffee, hoppy, nutty. Quite good.
Biscuit malt aroma, with a US style hop influence in the background . Very complex for a 5% beer.

On tap at CBC15. Amber with off white head. Aroma malty, biscuit, faint roasted, hops, pine and light caramel. Taste is bitter and sweet, a bit thin, grain, bread, biscuit with a fairly high bitterness.

Lukt: Humle, malt og karamell.
Utseende: Dunkel rødbrun farge.
Skum/kullsyre: Mye skum, heng langs kant.
Smak: Humle, malt og karamell.

Bottle. Pours clear brown, with a big cola coloured creamy head. Aroma is nice roasted malts, with bread and caramel, nuts and some phenolic smoky notes, as well as earthy hops with a spicy zest and some citrusy notes. Medium body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is caramelised malts, with grain, bread, kandi, nuts and wood, as well as bitter hops, with spruce and zesty citrusy notes. Lingering grapefruity finish.

Malts, caramel, dried fruits, toast and a hint of citrus in the aroma. Amber with a off-white head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with a soft carbonation. Overall an enjoyable ESB, quite malt driven but with an balancing bitterness.

From tap at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2015, Green session. Amber orange color with off white head. Malty and hoppy aroma, light roasted, caramel, toffee, citrusy, pine. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Almost medium oily body with soft carbonation.

22 oz. bottle at home. Pours a slightly hazy tea like brown color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted bread, caramel, some fruity hop character, mild citrus, floral, some cookie like malts, interesting, tasty bitter.

Draught at CBC 2015.
Clear orange coloured with a small off-white ehad.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and rbead.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, bread and hops.
Hoppy finish.
red brown pour. some tan head. citrus leaves leather. Tastes grassy malty tobacco slight caramel. rye like spice. chocolate. toasted grains. high carb. finish well balanced 60% bitter and 40% sweet.

@green cbc 2015
very smooth,light bitter, medium sweet, full body, could drink this all day long
Chestnut brown off white head. Aroma toasty and grainy. Taste is bready with tobacco, some nuttiness and burnt toast and earthy hops.
Pours clear amber. aroma is malty, taste is malty, nice balance. refreshing.

Bottle. Deep amber, clear. Rich bready caramels, slight chocolately, herbal, almost black tea-y, hoppyness on nose. Med bodied, med bittered, dry bready herbal finish. Clean, flavourful. Ok, decent drinker, easily likable.
How: Bottle Appearance: hazy chestnut color, small creamy off-white head. Aroma: Very fruity, caramel, notes of citrus and grass. Palate: medium body, average carbonation.

Pours a hazy dark orangey-brown with a small white head. Subtle aroma of earthy hops with just enough caramel malt to balance it out. Flavour is a perfect balance of sweet malt and fruity hops -- its really tasty and goes down so easy. Medium bodied.
I really enjoyed this. More full flavored than a traditional bitter you'd get in England. Well balanced.

Bottled on: xx/1x/14 ( wytarta ). Barwa bursztynowa, piana średnia, składająca się z drobnych i średnich pęcherzyków, dość szybko opada. Wygląda na to, że piwo które piłem, było już dość stare a co za tym idzie ułożone. Aromaty nie były tak wyraźne jak moża by się spodziewać po wiekszości ocen. W smaku "wypłowiałe", biszkopty i lekka owocowość. Z wszystkich piw AleSmith jakie miałem okazje próbować, to zrobilo na mnie najmniejsze wrażenie.

Clear copper with dense white head. Aroma is herbal, earth, citrus and British fruity yeast. Fruity, herbal, spicy, citrus and floral aftertaste. Overall: Excellent! Alesmith creates some of the best "Sipping beer in front of the fireplace" beers, and this is no exception. I´m not a fan of esb, but this one is pure craftsmanship.

1 pt 6 fl oz bottle. Deep copper amber colour, foam white head leaving lacing and aroma of toffee, orange marmalade. Taste is bready malty with toffee, caramel, and fruity earthy bitterness. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry dusty bitter finish. Nicely drinkable.

Deep amber colour with a thick cream head. Sweet metallic aroma. Slightly burnt toffee notes from the kettle caramelisation followed by some well balanced piney, herbal bitterness. 

Rated by BrewTom
On draft. Copper color with one finger off white head. Earthy and caramel aroma. Taste is similar with a little hop. Very good ESB.

Poured a rich ruby hued copper with an offwhite head that left thick lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, sweet caramel and toffee malt, a hint of toast and floral hops. Flavor is a balanced mix of fruity caramel malts, toast with a faint hop presence. Medium bodied with present carbonation. Chewy bodied with minimal bitterness. Very enjoyable and sweet,

Tap at brewery. Pour clear copper with creamy white head. Aroma is caramel and cereal malts, floral hops, faint spice, and faint pear. Flavor is a delicious combination of lightly, caramel sweet malts aside smooth hop notes with a touch a dry, citrus peel. Medium body and carbonation.
Very easy to drink. Great malt balance with touch of light bitterness. Pours brown hazy with ok head and lacing. Tap at Rattle N Hum.

Appearance was clear ruby amber with creamy off white diminishing 1/2 finger head, rings of lacing. Aromas are toast, nut, soft fruity esters with slight Maris otter malt sweetness, no alcohol. Taste are fruity esters upfront gives way to soft malt sweet middle. The soft woodsy, herbal, spicy hops are a good balance to a wonderful English water yeasty finish. Palate was smooth creamy CO2 with light-medium body, then a lasting balanced slightly dryish finish. Overall a stellar example of an ESB.

Rød klar skum råhvid 
Malt citrus brød nødder 
Bitter modrate sød lidt 
Crement blød 
@home
Bottle - clear amber with slim white head. Aroma of caramel malts, floral hops, spice. Taste is fruity, hoppy, malty. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Nice, drinkable bitter.

Bottled 650ml. -from Svijet Piva Zagreb. Frans bottle shared with Yves, Marko and me. Clear amber coloured, medium sized pale beige head, dry and dusty dog food nose (not so pleasant). The taste is much better; Toasted malt, caramel, dried fruits and touch of dog food with nutty notes in the finish. Not so sweet as Ive expected. Ok beer.

Huge thanks to Fran for this! Poured a superb, lovely ruby/amber bod ywith a small off white head. Aroma... caramel, slightly woody, raisins, dust, light chocolate, nice really, but not thrilling. Taste... caramel, light dry dog food, vague herbal notes, sweetish maltiness... I didnt like it much at first, but the superb, silky mouthfeel makes this one a grower... definitely a well executed beer, even if the style isnt my favorite. Good job!

Color caramelo claro con espuma beige cremosa que deja lazo y apenas mancha.
Olor a caramelo con toque metálico y maltoso.
Entra amarga de paso cremoso y dulce para repunte acaramelado meloso afrutado. Fondo ligeramente metálico y lupulado afrutado. Se nota que es una bitter al final.
http://goikodastaketa.blogspot.com.es/

Bottle shared at a tasting at Stass place. Thanks Excellent Little Brother! Dark amber with white film. Sweet, sugary, cake aroma, bitter and malty, mildly grainy taste. Medium body, mildly bitter finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks kerenmk. Hazy amber with a creamy head. Smell of caramel, bread and earthy hops. Taste - sweet, caramel malts, biscuits, nuts, light fruitiness, medium herbal bitterness, feels a bit old. Medium body and carbonation. Decent.
Draught at Pacific Standard. Rich amber color with creamy beige head, spciy aroma, high carbonation, caramel taste, medium finish, bitter aftertaste. A very good ESB.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Stass place. Thanks kerenmk. Hazy amber. Aroma of malt, biscuit, a roasted chocolate note, nuts and an earthy hops touch. Sweetish malty flavor with biscuit, toast, nuts and a bitterish finish with some hops. Medium-bodied.
Rating this a five based purely on style...a perfect ESB. Great earthy hops,seems of noble variety, floral malt flavor a perfect ESB!

Super intense, barley winey aroma- caramel, berries, maltiness- wow. Pours casual in the glass- bubbly, spongey, thick, finger wide top. Taste- medium sweet, light bitterness; smooth, soft palate. Very drinkable and pleasant; only alarm was untypical strong malt bill versus light hops presence in flavor.  Medium bodied

Malty background, caramel, some light fruitiness, bit hops. Quite light medium bodied, but well balanced. Promising nose, but taste makes question myself - why I didnt just grab a barley wine. Decent, but nothing to remember.

September 8th, 2011 - September 8th, two days before my birthday, marked my first visit to my new neighbor, Alesmith. A full tasting run would require a full belly, some stamina, and starting with the lighter brews. Accompanied only by my notepad and the unfortunate dearth of light caused by a city wide blackout, I began reviewing the Ale Smith Anvil ESB - one of the finest and most engaging ESBs Ive ever had the pleasure to put to my taste buds. The aroma leads with a nice fruity start, adding in the artificial but frankly delicious taste of light brown sugar. Its nice, but not remarkable. That comes in the flavor which leads with a duet of caramel and a smoky peatiness. The caramel levels off eventually, leaving a deeply sweet peat in the aftertaste, and a feeling of richness (a sensation that is, for me, very rare with ESBs.) The Anvil is a solid caramel and malt laden brew with a nice hops leg and a twist of peat character that bodes well for the rest of the miniature glasses lined up before me and ready for rating.

Dunkel hopfiger und frisch herber Beginn. Das Bier ist klar bitterhopfig und weich durchgehend dunkle Getreidenoten auf, die Bitterkeit sinkt mit der Zeit. Süß malzige Noten, geringe Fruchtigkeit. Heuartig karamelliges Ausklang. Ein rundes und gutes Bier, ganz einfach! 10/12/12/10/10/11

Bottled (backlog, somewhere in Stockholm). Amber colour with a big beige head that leaves some lace and is quite longlasting as well. Aroma is sweet malts along with some caramel and crystal malts, mild rye bread, nuts as well as some slight herbal and floral hoppyness. Flavour is caramel malts, floral and grassy hoppyness with some mild zestyness, fudge and ryebread. Aftertaste is sweet malts along with some zesty and floral notes.

Clear darker copper with fair, creamy, orange head / Mild, fresh nose of spun sugar and citrus / Light to medium body, hint of sugary sweetness but mostly dry and thin of fruit, with modestly bitter finish / Flavors of toast and grain, with faint notes of grapefruit, caramel, and spun sugar / Maybe I am expecting too much of a pale ale style delivery, but the very dry, rather thin, flavor profile is lacking.

bottle from ølbutikken, shard with gitte.
cloudy brown, huge smooth light brown head.
malty,caramelly, nutty, slightly roasted aroma.complex, flowery notes from hops.flavor is malty, flowery and bitter hoppy, herbal notes (hops i guess), sweet sugary notes, quite tasty but nothing special really. some bitter nutty notes.

A dark copper brew with a tan head. This stuff really sucked cold, so I let it sit out for a couple of hours. Slightly better at room temperature, but still very funky. Heavy with lots of sweet malts. Some prune-raisin notes. Dry bittering backside. Too heavy for an ESB in my opinion. Not something Id buy again.

650ml bottle. Clear deep red glowing dark amber with huge firm frothy to creamy lacing yellowish tan head. Minimally sweet fruity aroma has notes of red currant and roast apple, some toasted malt. Smooth, soft-silk palate. Overall mild, though slightly spicy, dry and roasty taste; dry, slightly bitter roasty finish. Very nice.

Draft at Bullfrog. Surprisingly drinkable for a beer called Anvil. Pours copper with an inch of rapidly disappearing white foam. Floral and grapefruit notes on the nose. Some nice bitterness on the tongue. Finishes clean.  When I hear the word bitter this is how I imagined the beer would taste. Its flavorful without being a hop bomb and makes an impact without it needing to be 10%.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a tawny, hazy orange, brown color with a huge rocky beige head. Pleasant nutty toasted malt aroma remiscent of caramel apples. Fragrant floral hops in nose as well. Tart toasted malt flavor balanced by a subtle citrus hop prescence. Some butterscotch, some bready malt character. Nice clinging lace right through to finish. Overall, a very good representation of the ESB style.

Bottle at home. Pours almost clear amber with a creamy steady off white head. Lots of caramel, hops, fruit, toasted malt and light tobacco. The flavour is toasted and light caramelish with light sour malty notes. Fruity hops and bitterness in the finish.
Bottle pours clear copper with a thin off white top. Scent is caramel and bready. Taste is toasted malts, caramel and bready.

Pour dark, hazel nutty-brown, with a small tan head.
Aroma is really malty of caramel, bread, slight nut, with a small grassy - hoppy thing going on. - Slight dark fruits in here as well.
Taste is quite sweet, with some slightly bitter notes.
Light medium body, with a rather flat carbonation.

Bomber courtesy of rlgk. Pours clear amber with a big frothy brownish white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, dark bread, hazelnuts, soap, almond milk, orange peal, grass, pine, wood, golden syrup and fudge. Taste is sweet, bitter and very tiny sour with burnt caramel, grass, wood, lemon zest, almonds, toffee, pine, dark bread, chestnuts and hints of caraway, lemon juice and lemon balm. Mouthfeel is slightly crisp, round and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with toffee, orange peal, grass and wood. Bit strange, especially the smell, but still good...
From a big bottle at home in Skövde. Clear beautyful amber beer with a big beige head. Hoppy, malty a bit nutty (almond) aroma. Similar flavour. A really nice beer.
Bottle. Amber beer with à nice beige head. Milky toffee aroma, vanilla, fruits, some almond, hay notes. Malty flavor, roasted, chocolate, sourish, fruity. Malty sourish finish.

650 ml bottle. Finland.
Reddish dark amber colour with small off-white head.
Berry fruity sweetish aroma with some maltiness.
Flavour is mild sweetish candy hops, mild bitterness and strong malt. Mild alcohol in aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Craft Brewers Conference 2012 
Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Yeast lie aroma bitter hops and toasty.  The flavor was filled with bittering hops and a great ESB Flavor.  Very tasty brew.

Its quite dark and has a fairly solid head. The malt in both taste and aroma is really english. Taste of bread, and with the bitterness of grass. Interesting for an ESB, but its still not really my style.

Probably the best ESB I've had in the states! Highly recommended if you're a fan of the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear amber mahogany pour thin creamy off white beige head light sticky lacing .... aroma of biscuity, caramel and roasted malts with a light hoppy/fruityness to it ..... taste is of roasted and caramel malts, moderate bitter hops and a fruity/earthy taste with a dry bitter bite ... sessionable and decent
Bottle. Sweet Esb with notes of burned caramel, almond and resin. Semi-dry finish. Smooth.

Bottle.
Pours red with a big yellowish head.
Nice brew, almost like a light UK barley wine. Big fruity with some resin.
En nas notem una dolçor amb tocs de poma vermella, terra, humitat, però molt suau. La carbonatació es mitjana. El sabor és bo amb notes de sègol, fulles, més tard caramel i una mica de pa.
Pours clear amber with a minimal head. Aroma fruits, hops. Slight sweetness. Medium light body. Not Bad.

Copper color, tan head. Roasted, nutty flavor. Dry finish with fruity notes. Pretty good balance. Medium body, medium carbonation. Not bad, fairly classic ESB.

660ml bottle (Viisi Pennia, Helsinki)
nice mashy aroma, dryish, some english hops. pleasan body, a little crisp in the carbonation, but that makes it quite refvreshing despite the rweidual sweetness. Retronasals are a little fruity, this is coming over as  pretty nice ale. Finish  is a touch mushroomy, but quite mellowp, and convincingly English. Not perfect, but still a good approximation to the English style, one of the better US attempts.

(Bottle, 0.65 l, at Oluttupa Viisi Penniä, 20120515) The beer poured brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, sweetness and hops. Palate was medium bodied with quite high carbonation. Flavours were hops, malts, molasses, fruitiness, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity, malty and bitter. Not an ordinary ESB but a tasty one.

650 ml bottle.
Pours a dark copper colour with an off-white head. Aroma of toasted malts, nuts and syrup. Flavour of toasted malts, nuts, dried fruits and grassy hops. Some floral notes also. Medium bodied, rough malty mouthfeel and a malty bitter finish. Nice American-style ESB.

660ml bottle from Høkeren

Pours dark brown with a smooth foamy head. Aroma of bready malts, hops, biscuity notes and fruits. Taste is malty with bready and biscuity notes, grassy hops and caramel. Finish is malty and bitter. Okay, quite tasty.

65 cl bottle @ hotel room in Copenhagen.
Pours clear copper color with minimal head. Aroma of caramel malts, fruits and biscuit notes. Flavor of sweetish caramel malts, biscuits, fruits, mild hay and some resin and pine needle notes.
4425

65 cl bottle @ hotel room, copenhagen
Aroma has bready malt, some english toffee and american hops. Also hints of hay. Flavour has bready malt, some english toffee and american hops in the background. Balanced and nicely hopped, but still blends to the ESB mass.

Location/Date:Bottle on May 6th, 2012.
Appearance:Pours a cloudy copper.
Aroma: Aroma is light piney bitterness.
Taste: Light bitterness, some citrus.
Palate:Medium-light body.
Summary: I enjoyed this beer, and at 5.5% could be a nice sessionable beer but its too hard to get on the East Coast.

Probably the best ESB that Ive had...so if you like the style jump on it, but its not my favorite variety.  

Pours brown, moderate head.  Palate is fairly flat,carmel, some hops on the back end.  More pronounced flavors than most ESBs but less than most beers that i drink.

Refreshing beer, goes down easily, if unremarkably.

terrific version of the style, maybe just a tick below the one that gets all the credit for being first, Fullers. Here on the East Coast, a lot of brewers make this same beer, but fail at the labeling. Most call theirs an IPA, and if they labeled it an ESB like Alesmith, it would make more sense. This has a great malt foundation that isnt sickly sweet or too bready, and of course coming from the West Coast, this has more grapefruit floral hoppiness to it. Delicious beer, but at the same time, not a session ale like a Fullers
#1461 bottle; nose is sweet rye, toffee, sweet red apple, apricot, damp earth, feel is medium, carb is medium, taste is stale pecan, rye note, leaves, later toffee, some bread

bottle, pours deep copper, small head, Aroma: Spicy, rye, solid malty, dusty, liquorice, grassy hops, fruity, cardboard, grain, caramel, toasty, bready, biscuits, Taste: Very balanced, malty sweetness, bready, liquorice hops, grassy, some bitterness, pretty dry,

Rich amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, floral hops, & some spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, hops, caramel, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, solid bitter - well made.

Bottle.  Pours amber with a finger of white head, solid lacing, and mild carbonation.  Aroma is very malt forward with some caramel, a little biscuit, and some sour notes.  Taste is fairly light, lightly bitter, and finished smoothly.  The palate is fairly full for the ABV level.  This almost seems like a light APA.

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear red/brown - white head. Roasted. Cocoa. Ok light bitterness. Fruity. High malty. Dry chocolate. Cocoa powder. Nutty. Breadish. Caramel notes. Light dried fruits. Nice balance.

Bottle.  Pours a dark reddish-brown with a frothy tan head.  Nutty aroma with a bit of caramel malt.  Fairly bitter on the palate, with astringent hops balancing out the rich malt flavors of caramel, nuts, and toast.  Slightly bready/yeasty finish.  A solid example of the style, although not a particularly exciting beer.
Poured a hazy copper color with a small off white head. Aromas of floral hops and caramel. Taste is sweet caramel, honey and floral hops.  Smooth and very drinkable.

Deep reddish copper color with a substantial off white head. Smooth but punchy, balanced with a kick. Malt is there with a hint of earthiness (pine) and hops kicking in (though not too floral or bitter). Perhaps a touch of grass, citrus zest, passion fruit, and broccoli.

bottle from Wegmans. pours a light to medium brown with red hew. nice head that lingers. nose is mild with english malt , almost lime citrus. first sip is malty smooth like a brown ale ut the finish is mild hop presence.

Poured from a bomber into a shaker pint glass. Appearance is dark amber with a two finger width head of sticky, crisp, white foam. Webby lacing down the side of the glass. The aroma is brimming with character; I get notes of caramel, malt sweetness, a touch of spicy, herbal hops, some fruit esters, just a fantastic aroma. Taste brings everything together for a wonderful joyride across the tongue. Medium sweetness, mild hop presence, a touch toasty, I couldnt ask for more. This beer kills. I would love to have this in the fridge at all times. Ultimate session beer, kinda. Thanks for picking this up for me, Weihenheizen.
Bottle. Red copper. Caramel, toasted, florals, candy, malts, fruits. Sweet, finishes a little bitter.

Bitter flavor, malty, and more bitter, also dry.  Sort of a lighter beer, not a lot of flavor in the middle but it is true to the style, nice copper appearance with a  touch of fruitiness as well.  Well done, a bit of a delicate beer.
Pours a beautiful ruby-copper with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet, floral, and citrus. Taste is malt and hops with a nice bitter finish. Very lively on the palate.

Had this on draft at Tam OShantern in Glendale. Copper color and nice foam head. Smells of malt and some hops. Taste is malt caramel with a nice hop finish. A very good bitter style beer, very impressed.
Bottle in AZ. Clear, copper orange appearance with a big tan head. Roasty, burnt caramel malty, light char, organic aroma. Burnt, charred caramel malty, spicy, organic, pesticide flavor. Gross.

22oz capped bottled poured into Sam Adams pint glass.   Pours a dark ruby color with a two finger, fizzy white head.   Smells of floral hops and sweet candy and caramel.   Bitterness right up front that mellows and leaves a malty taste.  Notes of caramel, bread and tea.  Mouth feel is creamy with moderate carbonation.  No ABV listed on the bottle.  A nice ESB and well worth a try.

Pours copper-mahogany into a Sam glass. Off-white head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Toasted caramel and resin aromas. Medium bodied with sweet summer fruit and honey-caramel upfront turning to mild citrus and resin in the lasting finish.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Pours dark copper color with off white head. Caramel malt aroma with some floral hops. Sweet caramel flavor with toasted malts, doughy yeast and moderate hop bitterness. Medium body with lively carbonation. Thanks Craig.
Bottle. Reddy brown with cream head. Fruity hop nose. Orangey malt sweetness. A delicious bitter.

I had very low expectations for this beer, thought how good could a bitter be?. Turns out the answer is pretty good. Looks incredible, pours chestnut red with off white head. Aroma has nuts, floral notes, caramel and a touch if citrus. Similar taste, incredibly well balanced. Slightly sweet with enough bitterness to clean away. This beer could possibly be seen as boring or possibly the work of genius. Id say the latter. Excellent
Pours a nutmeg brown with little head, aroma is a little sweet and malty. Sits a bit heavy in the mouth, not the standard ESB for sure.

A - hazy  burnt orange with  low tan head that dissipates quickly. S - aromas of citrus hops (grapefruit), biscuity and caramel malts. Hints of metal and lager notes. M - high carb brew with medium body, very dry. Lingering malty metallic. T - citrus hops, honey, and lager in the nose. Grapefruit, biscuits, and metal on the palate. Lingering malty ending.  Bitter throughout. O - pretty good esb.  Nice drinkable and smooth 6+

Poured from a bomber to a pint glass. Deep amber in color with a beautiful red tint. Nice tan head that left pretty good lacing. Smells of caramel, biscuit, and slight floral notes. Thin body, with tastes that start out with biscuit, moving to a slight alcohol taste, and ending with a mild bitter finish. Overall, the beer was ok, but reminded me of a basic amber ale.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 Bottle. Seriously good looking beer with a deep mahogany  color and a huge full pint lasting head that jiggles above the rim of the glass.  Aroma is clean deep malt, butter cookie, fruity, and orangey hop.  Flavor is mildly sweet with a little citrus acidity and bitterness. Full soft palate that dries quickly and cleanly.  I think it is better and certainly fresher than any English ESB Ive had in the US or my limited opportunities in the UK.  It seems to be an fair representation of the style.  I could very happily drink this all night.

Thanks to t0rin0 for sending this bottle my way. Served in a Bells tulip pint glass.

Pours a moderate brown-amber color with a good off-white head and a nice bit of lacing on the way down. Collar throughout. The nose brings some light floral and earthy hops. A bit of bready malt. Flavor has a nice bitterness mixed with light hop flavor and bready malt through the background. Really excellent balance. Light-medium body and a semi-dry finish. Really nicely done ESB.

Solid ESB.  Good, sweet, toasty malt aroma.  Perfect clear brown with a slightly tan head that clings to the glass.  Flavor is sweet malt, and earthy, toasty note or two, and a slightly bitter and dry finish.  I like it.
Bottle @ Brewdog Glasgow. Bordeaux red colour, thin off-white head. nose is fruity, malty, bit of biscuit. A bit hoppy. Flavour is light malty, fruity, bit woody and hoppy. Slightly bitter finish.
Bottle @ BrewDog Glasgow. Reddish brown colour, reasonable head. Fruity hop aroma. Blunt fruity malt flavour, bitter aftertaste. An American interpretation of a British beer which doesnt quite work.

Strong malty caramel/vanilla on the nose accompanied by nut and bread. Nice amber color with a medium foam top. Pleasant fruity bitterness with a small malty background. Big carbonated taste with a fruity/spicey finish. Overall, this is a pretty decent beer with a large fruity presence. Some earthy/piney hop background and pleasant malt presence. Id give this a C+ rating

Copper-bodied and carbonated like a canned ginger ale. Demonstrates the appealing malt and hop bitter balance one desires of an ESB. A hint of sea air and crackers along with a prick of cidery melanoidins. Balanced body with some toasty caramel malt as advertised. Easy fruity esters, a touch of cardboard and melanoidin. Approachable, if not remarkable.

(22oz bomber thanks to Mora2000) lasting thick creamy tan head atop a cloudy copper body. Nose of cracker, dry grain, bandaid and plastic. Taste of sweet grain, cracker, light caramel, stale and vanilla. Medium carbonation, creamy body and a caramel linger.
Pours copper with beautiful thick tan head.  Classic esb aroma and flavor: toffee, caramel, English hops... really a comfort beer. Nice nutty notes and lightly roasted malt.
Bottle. Pours a clear orangish brown. Light head. Aroma is light malts, sweet grains. Flavor is sweet notes and dry grains. Some raisins.
bought at AJs during trip to phx; did not like this one!  aroma was of barnyard and booze.  taste had no barnyard but had a wine/bourbon thing going on - did not enjoy at all...

650mL bottle pours a nice amber color with off-white head which has great retention and leaves nice lacing behind.  Aroma of roasted malts and some citrusy hops.  Taste is caramel sweetness balanced nicely with some fruitiness and a mild hop bitterness in the finish.  Nice carbonation and modest body leave a nice feel on the tongue.  This beer is full flavored yet smooth and easy to drink.  Very enjoyable.

GABF 2011.  Very dark nutty copper, nice creamy off beige head. Aroma of brown sugar, pecan and caramel. Flavor had some nice nutty caramel toffee tone, with a nice bitter finish. Balanced and lovely.

Not much hop to it at all, more on the lines of a scotch or dark for me. It didnt have have that refreshing bitterness I expected. Very malt forward, metallic, caramelly and quite dark. Not what I was expecting at all from this dark red brew.  Not much head on it either.  A bit disappointing.

Pours a caramel/brown color with a thin tan head...lively.  aroma has caramel, some nuttiness, some earthy notes, and a bit of fruit...not sweet.  Flavor is very nutty with hints of chocolate, fruity yeast notes, and a bit of caramel.  Mouthfeel is silky and the finish is lightly roasty with a hint of nuts and chocolate.
Tap.  Pours a light brown with noticeable carbonation and a soft white head.  Aroma of green apples.  Taste is slightly sour and bitter.

22oz  Auburn pour with small eggy head. Lots of carbonation.Slightly sweet toasted malts and light fruity esters. Medium slightly creamy body  Dry bitter finish. Slightly sweeter than id like. Almost too spicy at times.  Good effort and lots of complexity.

Bottle at Brewdog Bar Aberdeen. It pours deep ruby-red, with a thin foamy beige head. The nose is wood, leather, chocolate, Christmas pudding and light spice. The taste is wood, nut, chocolate, light roast, soft fruit (plum, fig, raisin, sweet raspberry) and light spice, with a long, dry finish. Medium body, fine carbonation and velvety mouth-feel. A well balanced and well put together ESB.
@ Alesmith. Brown pour with white head. No aroma. taste is thing with caramel malts. Thin finish.

Draft at Alesmith tasting room with Andrew, Brendan and the big boy daddy dad Bachelor, Dallas. Pours a dark, hazy amber with light lacing. Aroma is sweet. Mouthfeel is light with notes of vanilla, malts, and some bready-yeast flavors. Weird finish of fish-tank water?

On tap at Alesmith with Dallas, Andy and James for Dallas bachelor weekend. Grainy, brown pour with a mocha-colored and whispy head. Aroma is sweet, surprisingly, and a hint of raisins? Flavor is very chocolatey, but leaves a light footprint and is pretty drinkable.
On tap at the brewery with the bros for dallas bachelor party.  Brown ale and Biscuity.  Some rich vanilla coming through.. Delicious and sessionable.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a clear amber/brown with a small white film. Aroma of fruits, wood, caramel malts, spice. Flavour of darker forest fruits, caramel malts, quite a lot of smouldering wood, spicy hops. Medium complexity, slightly thin - not too surprising considering the style. They did a good job though,

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 22 oz. bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours a clear dark red / amber with a small head. Nose is unusually strong for the style, with lots of slightly burnt caramel malt, wood, bittering hops, and some orange / lemon rind. Flavour features an array of fruity esters, woody / caramel malts and some spicy, zesty hops. As the style goes, this is wonderful - count on AleSmith to follow through.
Copper tan head. A straight-up perfect ESB. Clean bitter finish. A hoppy flowery taste with a toasted malt touch. Smells like sweet hops.

Poured from the bottle it formed a good size beige head in the glass with a hazy brown color. It has a honey and sweet aroma and some citrus to it. The taste is very smooth and mild with a caramel, toffee and some vanilla. Nice long finish.

A: The beer pours a dark amber color with a couple fingers of white head and some mild lacing.

S: Heavy on the caramel and toffee malts with some traditional English hop aromas.  A nice earthy and floral hop character to this one with a hint of pine.  Some mild cocoa and toasted bread, as well as some yeast, on the back end.

T: The flavor is similar to the aroma.  Just a touch of citrus, but mostly floral and earthy hops with a mild bitterness to the beer.  Sweet toffee, bread, and caramel hops with plenty of toasted character.

M: Medium to full bodied with a medium level of carbonation.

O: Like most Alesmith beers, really solid stuff.  I could have used a little less sweetness, but the beer was still enjoyable.

bomber purchased at BevMo - Escondido.  pours a deep ruby color with a very thin white head - low carbonation.  caramel malt nose with some bread notes and light earthy hops.  light to medium body - filled with dark fruit notes, bread, sweet malts and a lingering bitterness.  sweet malt / caramel finish with lingering raisin and grape notes.

Pour was a rich amber color with very minimal light head.  Aroma was fruity and slightly sweet with some citrus character.  Taste was very light and balanced with nice fruity malts and little hops. One easy drinking beer that got better as it warmed a bit.

On tap at the brewery, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear dark copper with a tall, dense tan head. The head fades to a thin cover and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose is toasty malty, with caramel, nuts, flowers and slight pine. The flavour is nicely balanced; it starts out moderately sweet but becomes gradually more bitter. There are notes of anise, nuts and bread throughout. The finish is long and toasty with subtle hops. On the palate, it is medium in body with a slightly dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a nice hoppy ESB with delicious nutty malts. 2011-06-05
Great light malty aroma, cloudy amber pour. Nutty flavors. Very light lingering happy finish. I started drinking this too cold and couldnt taste anything.
Thin head minimal lacing.  Bomber from Super Jr. San Diego.  Magenta brown.  Somw sweet malt on nose.  Terrific balance and full, rounded palate.  Great representation on the style.
anyone that doesnt appreciate this doesnt understand fine ales. most beer geeks arent trained in ales, only ipas and barleywines. this is actually better than fullers esb.
Bottle shared with some friends. Dark brown color. Slightly over carbonated. Aroma is slightly roasty with hints of booze and caramel. Flavor is semi sweet and pretty easy to drink.
Caramel malt / fruity grass aroma. Caramel malts /toasted grains and ripe fruit taste.  A mild dry bread finish. Interesting , but not life altering.

Light biege head small misty burnt sienna coloured pour aromas floral rich malt fruit beery note flavour floral berries rich fruit toffee smooth bitter not strong finish the aftertaste sweet malt hop fruit floral berry cherry like sweet ale mild bitter nothing special

On tap at the tasting room. It pours dark reddish brown with a thin khaki head. The aroma is malty with toffee, cocoa, big raisin and plum with touches of molasses. The flavor is lighter and less potent than the aroma with lots of fruity raisiny malt, a touch of buttered toffee and finishes with very little hop presence. I enjoyed this one.

Poured into a pint glass. Got accepted to med school today, so time to celebrate!

3.0 A: Translucent amber brown color. Less than one finger of creamy dark beige head with below average retention but a good amount of lacing considering the original head size.

3.5 S: Grainy, and to a less extent bready, malts. Caramel, toasty, and maybe a bit nutty. Good, but lacking in strength.

3.5 T: Like the nose, the taste is a light as well. Caramel, toasty, and grainy malts are the strongest. Hops add a soft bitterness with an earthy herbal taste. Light general fruitiness.

3.5 M: Light body, perhaps too light. Good moderate carbonation. Could be creamier and a thicker body would help with that. Otherwise, okay.

3.5 D: A while ago I made the mistake of comparing every bitter to East Ends Bitter End (the 2nd running of Gratitude) and so very few have been able to meet the complexity and straight up great taste. This is no different. Anvil is a pedestrian attempt at a pedestrian style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-17-2010 23:21:47

Dark amber pour, with a hint of cloudiness and lots of bubbles, including large ones, rising from the bottom of the glass.  What little head there was dissipated quickly.  Good, full malty aroma, but not overpowering.  The flavor has a low malty point and a high citrusy point, almost orange, with a large gap between.  Large bubbles in the mouth take away from the mouthfeel.  I like it.
Pours brown with a medium head.  Malty and fruity on the nose.  Taste of fruit, malt, and spicy hops.  Very drinkable but I enjoyed the all English ingredients version better.

22oz bottle from Phil 
Appearance: Pours clear brown/copper with a medium sized off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, caramel and spices 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, yeasty with some hop bitterness in the finish 
A nice ESB, easy drinking

Bottle. Thanks to BMan1113VR! Pours lightly hazy caramel amber, thick persistent off-white head, spotty lacing. Nose is citrus hops, spice, earth, caramel/toffee, light tropical fruit, some odd yeasty/estery notes that Im not exactly digging. Flavours of earth, swert toffee and fruit, some real boiled vegetables throughout... You know, the more I drink this, the less I like it. Im a HUGE Alesmith fan, but I kinda hate the shit outta this. This is genuinely unpleasant. Ass, Ill pass.

Dark brown thin head slightly hazy. Very strong hop aroma. Very English hops in the aroma.  Wow! Now that is a bitter . Lots of English hops grassy, malty and sweet. With lots of caramel. Very nice beer. Not a typical ESB. More like an ESB on steroids but i like.

How is this a 100 in the ESB style?  I was all geeked up to try this brew, but it let me down!  First off..."sparkling clarity"?  Its a ruddy iced tea color.  Foam retention?  Ya know what, I think I got the wrong beer.

Anyway, aroma is quite appealing, with heavy toast, caramel/sugar, and pale sweet fruit.  Flavor is wild ride, and not at all what I was expecting.  Mouth-puckering bitterness comes along with champagne yeast and fruity hops.  Balance seems to be way off on this one, lacking the malty backbone alluded to by the smell.
Full bodied beer. Lots of toffee and a little chocolate. Bold english hops. Like a craft Old Speckled Hen.

Pours amber color and has a huge light tan head. The aroma is a strange mix between tang and brown sugar with an awkward weirdness. Taste is sort of stale and apple-y but has a very apparent extract note. Medium body, but pretty true to style. Got better as I drank more. Still not great.

Bottle from Secret Summer Santa.  Bad band-aid nose, oxidized and astrigent.  Stale and Extracty, a touch of fruit, bitter, mildly.  After breathing a bit, the flavors mellowed, lots of caramel with some fruit, a mild toastiness.  Not bad.  A little put off by the initial nose.

I was elated to see this beer in a box from Hayduke.  A deep copper hue on the pour and a very big fluffy tan head that ever so slowly collapses.  A fetching aroma of fruit, yeast, spice, and hops.  Some nice  bitterness on the front end with lightly sour fruit, biscuit, toffee coming a bit later.  Finish was sour, fruity, and clean.  A very nice beer.
I really enjoyed this ESB.  AleSmith has impressed me and this was just another win.  Very refreshing and crisp.

Pours with a nice head that doesnt hang around too long (but which made the first sip extra tasty).  Smells of toffee, caramel, slightly bready with a little touch of floral hops. Taste is perfect.  All of the above-mentioned aromas pass as flavors over your tongue with a fleeting bitter finish. In between dry and full finishes.  The carbonation is not tight but still helps the flavors pop off your tongue while the "wetness" of it still coats the mouth.  Excellent beer.

On tap at Fathers Office SM. Pours hazy amber with white head. Aromas of biscuity malts, toffee, caramel, earthy hops, and citrus. Flavors of fruity malts, toffee, caramel, citrus, and some hops. Easy drinking ESB. Good stuff.

On tap @ Alesmith. Copper in color with a small beige head. Aroma of fresh baked biscuits, earthy hops, caramel and light lemon. The flavor is smooth and malty with a light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation and a clean, smooth finish. Great example of an under appreciated style.

on tap at the brewery. pours a dark, reddish-brown with a thin, light khaki head and light lacing. aroma is very nice with dry, nutty malts and dry grass up front backed by light citrus hops, toast, toffee, and a touch of tropical fruit. flavor is damn nice with notes of orange peel, dry grass, and nutt malts up front backed by burnt caramel and hints of coffee. palate is medium bodied with solid carbonation and a dry, bitter, nutty finish. overall, a very good esb.
Bottle purchased at City Beer. Clear amber pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma is malty with some caramel and earthy hops. Malt flavor with caramel and a bit of fruit before a dry hoppy finish.
Dark amber with a reddish tint. White head that hung around. Very malty sweet aroma. Sweet taste that gets a bit bitter but  very smooth. Nice finish that leaves you wanting another.

reddish brown with substantial white head. front forward light caramels with some cereal flavors. some citrus hop notes and otherwise substantially hopped. missing some fruit esters. still the cleaner profile is appreciated and delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 Tasted from bottle purchased at City Beer. Pours a deep amber cooper with a thick tan head that sticks around with nice lace. Nose is a strong aroma of caramel malt with very light citrus hops and a hint of yeast earthiness. Flavor is the same starting off with the sweet malts and moving to fairly light citrus bitterness and finishing with even stronger bitterness. The body is light with average carbonation and a long bitter finish.

This poured a nice mahogany color with a huge beige head. Aroma was light caramel and light citrus and grassy hops. Flavor was much the same, very subdued but light caramel hops and even a mild sour note. Interesting stuff for an ESB.

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ Alesmith. The aroma has some flowery hops and caramel malts. Clear, amber-brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is a bit sweet, moderate bitter and has caramel malts, little roast, some hops. Good.

The aroma immediately reminded me of the milk caramels my mom makes around the holidays. Darkish malt backbone, dried fruit flavors and moderate, resinous hoppiness with little actual bitterness - more like a tangy, dry quality than bitter - malt and hops are extremely well balanced. Almost seems to me like some rye is in here given some of the flavors, though I highly doubt it. This beautiful redhead is of the most flavorful, complex beers under 6% Ive had in a while.

Pours dark - a deep ruby amber, with a beige head. Smells like caramel-colored overripe fruit. Slightly toasty - like slightly overcooked caramel - but theres really a lot of fruit in here. Some baking spices... very, very little hop flavor - it really only comes through on the aftertaste, which I found disappointing. This is good, but probably at the bottom of the list of things Ive had from AleSmith.
A pretty dark esb, not much hops on the nose and not a whole lot of hop flavor but a good level of bitterness and drinkability.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark amber with a small white head leaving significant lacing on the glass.  A bit of hops on the nose with caramel malt dominating.  Taste is of caramel hops with a bit of bitter hops.  Clean finish.  Tasty beer.
Pours a copper color with a thin head to it. Has a nice caramel smell to it. Taste is mainly caramel with a slight bitterness to it.

Bottle. Pours garnet-brown with off-white head. Aroma is very rich - fruity, mild berry notes, some nuttiness in the background. Round malt flavor - textured grains,  caramelized sugars, light toasted barley - followed by mild bitterness and very light herbal/piney hops. Unbeatable palate and very clean. A good ale on the darker side, definitely reminiscent of the better English ESBs.

dark reddish brown, dark for the style, large white head.  rich malt and slight floral hop to the nose.  moderate bitterness followed by a lot of rich low crystal malt, possibly even a little chocolate malt in there before a lot of fruity esters from the yeast that are nice.  a fair amount of residual sweetness.  a tasty brew, but somewhat unusual for the style, a bit too sweet and with too little hop character

Bomber served in an English pint. Pours amber-brown with a slight haze and a good-sized beige head. Aroma is mellow chocolate and caramel malt, a touch of fruit, and a spice and hop kick. The slightly bittersweet flavor and creamy texture is classic English-style bitter. Medium body and smooth finish. Excellent malt components in this easy-drinking brew.

bomber from a trade with Lagunitasfan, shared with jsprime. deep ruby with a tan head. hopped up ESB aroma. classic ESB malt body with lots of english hopping. best ESB ive had, id love to session this beer. thx for the trade tim.

22oz bottle.  thanks to ken for the extra....pours a semi-transparent dark tea-like brown with a medium creamy light beige head.... aroma of grassy herbalness pervades with some accompanying light fruit notes... flavors have some caramel toasted malt  to coincide with some earthy light herbal bitterness.  semi-sweet overall without any lingering bitterness.  smooth easy drinking.  almost more of a lightly hopped brown ale to me.

Deep red in color, clear with a small white head which gathers around the edges. Toasted malt. caramel, herb-like and fruity hops. The palate is light-medium in body, flat carbonation with a soft finish. The taste is sweet with caramel malt and light fruit and finishes with a subtle tea-like leafy bitterness. Enjoyable with lots of character.
Pours a dark ruby red with a big frothy tan head. Not much of a nose on this one besides some caramel malts. Sweet, very malty with a bitter finish. Disappointing, but still drinkable.

Alesmith
Anvil ESB
Pours copper with a super thick off white head and 50 miles of retention. Had to let it sit for several minutes waiting for the head to die down. Somewhat hoppy dry aroma with a metallic tinge. Little bit of paint and/or band aid aroma. Not very nice. Tastes better than it smells with a subdued malt flavor and not a lot of bitter. Some earthy hoppiness, but not a lot. Underwhelming and plastic. Probably wont buy again. Disappointing, and I burp a funky plastic flavor.

Pours a nice dark redish copper color with a short lived head.The aroma was a sweet fruit candy.The taste was a bland sweet flavor.The finnish a weak bitter aftertaste.I would have expected much better from a top brewer like AleSmith.

lucent coper, thick sudsy beige head, medium body, low fine co2.

aroma: very vinyl hop, dish soap.

taste:
T1= very vinyl, latex paint.
T2= very mineral, slight caramel malt not trying to break through.
T3= minerality, diacetyl.
Massive head. Almost no beer on first pour. Chestnut brown. Aroma of spicy hops, pine, grass and sugar. Flavor of Berry, roasted malt, diacetyl, earth hops and grain.

After trying Fullers ESB I have been on a quest to find other similar beers.  Id say this exemplifies the category quite well, though I think its just a little bit too sweet for my taste.  Its very good overall and Ill try it a few more times to solidify my opinion but if memory serves me, the Fullers ESB is likely to be purchased more frequently by me.
Dark copper color with lasting foam. Earthy, spicy hops, caramel-toast malt, fruitiness. Nice carbonation and a clean bitter finish.
Not one that I really liked. It was extremely fizzy and pretty bitter. I didnt enjoy it that much.
From a 22oz bottle,Not really a style i like. Red in a color  and very bitter.

22 oz. bottle via trade with LtDan- thanks again, Dan!  Pours a dark mahogany color, not opaque but very rich in hue.  Small beige head that leaves a film on top of the beer.  Aroma of grassy hops, rye, toasted malts, toffee, citrus, cherry, and wood.  Flavor of toasted malts, earthy hops, tea, grass, toffee, rye, citrus, apple, and wood.  Dry, earthy, and malty.  Light-medium bodied, with gentle carbonation and a dry finish.  Well-balanced, smooth, and subtle.  Really nice to drink.  I generally dont get too excited about what is usually a pretty boring style, but this is the best premium bitter/ESB Ive ever had.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, nuts, toasting, light piney hops, and a hint of caramel.  Poured mahogany/deep amber in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Slightly sparkling.  Full of small particles throughout.  Good lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, nuts, toasting, light caramel, light fruit, light hops, slight citrus, slight grain, slight wood, and a hint of orange marmalade.  Medium body.  Creamy, slightly tingly, then lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Nut, malt, toasting, and light citrus hop finish is lightly dry.  Disappointing for AleSmith, but not bad.

Bottle from brewolf...thanks Michael! - Pours a deep amber with a creamy off-white head. Smells of light and biscuity malt, nutty with a nice herbal hop burst and some light sweetness. Tastes real bready and yeasty, with some light toffee and a smooth herbal hop bitterness on the finish. A touch of milky sourness creeps in there too. Mild and easy-drinking, well-balanced and harmonious. If this was sold in WI, I could see this being a go-to beer that I could drink all night.

Aroma was of caramel, resin pine, slight hops. Appearance was a deep copper color. Was expecting the head to be gigantic, going by the alesmith IPA. But was suprised by it being very tiny. The taste was interesting. But kind of dissapointing, in a way. I was expecting something Extra Special Bitter. But was not really bitter at all. Had a slight alcohol presence. Not very fond of that, But an exellent beer, just was expecting something else. Overall great. Definitly will be trying alesmiths other brews.

Not my first time trying, just my first time rating it.   Its a very nice ESB, although light on the bitter side.  Pours a clear copper color with a tiny offwhite foam head that sticks around.  Lacing is nice.  Aroma, is difficult for me to rate after mowing the lawn....I just smell myself...This brew has a relatively simple smooth taste and mouthfeel.  The flavor dissipates as quick as slides down your throat.   No aftertaste.  At first I thought this was denoted a beer without complexity, but thinking back to other esbs this is more of a positive element of this brew.  Another fine libation from AleSmith.

Finally got to try this.  Pours amber with a decent size tan head.  Light aroma of caramel, roasted malt, some pine.  Good smooth flavor, with the malt flavor doing the dominating.  Very easy to drink.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 Bomber. Pours a dark, coppery amber color with a half inch of milky, bubbly head. Aroma is very faint floral hops and barley. The taste begins with tart fruit flavors (apricot, cherry, cranberry) and toasted malts followed by spiced hops and a hint of barley. It finishes crisp and dry with a little sour bitterness at the end. Doesnt taste anything like the English ESBs that Ive tried and I definitely wasnt expecting the fruit flavors. Very smooth and unique brew.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 This is my first ESB so I cant necessarily rate it based on style, but considering that it is from AleSmith it is probably one of the best of its style. Apart from agreeing with what everyone else is saying about the flavor I would like to add that it actually reminded me of trail mix (nuts and dried fruit) and a little bit of smokey tones. Which is great because I love trail mix. This was a near perfect beer(from my limited experience) and I highly, highly recommend it. PS: The only set back is that if youre not careful you WILL get a cup full of head. The first glass I poured was only moderately gentle and I ONLY got head. Second pour was as gentle as I could be and it was half head. In a way I kind of like that though

Location: On tap at the Brewery, 1/8/10 


Aroma: Malty, caramel, some smoke, floral hops, and some spice

Appearance: Copper color with a tan head

Flavor: Balanced, malts are dominant, but it is somewhat bitter considering the style

Palate: Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, smooth finish

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty solid beer.  Not a crazy brew by any means, but a nice example of the style.  Look, I liked every single beer I had at AleSmith, and while this one wasnt nearly my favorite, it was no exception.

Pours a very deep dark coppery chestnut brown with dark mahogany edges that is completely opaque with a very thin off white head that quickly fades into a thin lasting ring.

Slightly hoppy aroma with a decent amount of sweet, slightly roasty malt, caramel malt and subtle chocolate and toffee notes. Im also picking up some subtle rye and more earthy hops toward the end of the nose.

Chewy full malty body with a prominent caramel malt presence that is slightly roasty as well as some toffee, rye and milk chocolate character. Its also pretty hop forward with a strong citrus peel presence and some earthy pine notes. This is quickly countered by the prominent malt profile but it lingers throughout into a sweet and slightly bitter dry finish. Pretty well balanced with a slightly more prominent hop profile. Kind of like a roided up American version of an English ESB.

A co-worker brought some Alesmith bombers back from CA for me (very cool dude) and this was one of them. The beer poured a nice dark orange which was almost brown. The head was large, white and rocky. The bottle conditioning really carbonates this beer as I got way too much foam even though I poured slowly and gently. The smell was a little malty and caramel but not much in the way of hop aromas. The taste was good with caramel coming into play and maybe it was citrus I was detecting. The drinkability was very good as my pint was gone fast. Mouthfeel really benefits from the bottle conditioning as the beer feels creamy in the mouth.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-12-2007 18:04:11
A deep amber color with a delicious, frothy head and a nice grassy aroma. Apple, pear, and caramel. A great ESB.

Pours a copper color with a nice foamy tan head.  aroma is of fruit esters, light malt. and a little hops.  flavor is of fruit esters, carmel malt, toasted malt, yeast, and dark fruit.  has a medium body with nice carbontaion and bitter finnish.  overall, a very tasty beer.

A delicious and well made ESB courtesy my Secret Santa. Thanks man! Its been a long time since Ive had an ESB, even longer since Ive had a good one. This is prefectly subtle. Aroma was light and fruity with a light maltiness. Pour was a beautiful medium brown with a one finger tan head. Taste was, again, subtle and delicious. Strong caramel malt with the fruity esters coming out more as the beer warms (actually gets too noticeable- which is a drawback). There is a nice toasty character in the aftertaste that rounds this beer off. Decent cabonation. Reminds me that we in the US can actually do a good ESB. Thanks!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours deep brown amber with a big tan head. Lots of lacing. Flavor is pair with apples, goes down easy, would make a great (and expensive) session beer.

Huge, bombastic levels of tart fruit envelop this particular beer. A smooth caramel color wraps around the glass, as a large cloud of foam erupts after the initial pour is completed. AleSmiths ESB is a bit too floral, with an almost syrupy fructose bite that kicks the tongue. Imagine drinking Hawaiian Punch that has been fermenting in a wood jug somewhere for years on end, and this would be the final product.  A little too much fruit for me, despite the aromic feel and lush coloring.

Wowee! An easy-to-medium pour just gave me, literally, a mug full of foam. Thick, creamy, tan colored foam. Almost like a Nitro-tap pour. After about eight minutes or so, it finally leaves me with a lightly amber tinted, golden colored liquid. Slightly darker than Im used to for an ESB, which pleases me. The lacing is spotty, plentiful, and sticky.

A fair amount of toasted malt presence is in the nose. Nice presence of floral hops. Light hints of apples and traces of dark fruits.

The taste follows the nose very well. Loads of that toasted malt flavor. It blends quite nicely with a balanced level of those wonderful floral hop notes. Light hints of granny smith apples and bing cherries. There is a very light hint of smokiness in the aftertaste.

This has a nice, medium, body. It has a medium-to-high level of carbonation. Its nice, little, small bubbles, which help it out. It is smooth, with a mild level of active-ness on your tongue. It has a slight touch of creaminess, which helps its enjoyability factor.

Traditionally, I am not big on the ESB style, but this is a definite exception. This is a beer that I could drink many of. Often.
Thank you, Alesmith!
Alesmith sure knows how to make good beer.  Pour is darken gold-red with a nice thick head.  Aroma is caramel malts, floral hops and citrus.  Flavor is a very solid bitter.  Palate is smooth.
Pours dark red brown with a thick and creamy tan head. Bitter and full bodied while maintaining a fruity and light quality accentuated by an interesting spice note.

Sampled from 22-oz bomber during Darkness Day 2009 in Brooklyn Center, MN. Pours a semi-clear brownish red colored brew with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates. Aroma of toasted caramel malt, light yeast, apple and floral hops. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of caramel malt, floral hops, some biscuit malt, hard fruit and some light spice. Finish is semi-sweet with a biscuit malt aftertaste that slowly disappears. Nice multi-personality ESB overall.
Septemberfest. Sample from a bottle thanks to nearbeer.  Clear red-orange, big sticky off white head.  Aroma is toasty, caramel.  Taste is grassy, caramel, biscuit.

Bomber. Pours an unclear deep brownish amber with a billowing, thick, rocky, tan head. Awesome retention and lacing. Aroma is HUGE baked cinnamon apples and pear with hints of apricots, strawberries, Malibu rum, pineapples, ambrosia. Holy.... Taste is big pear with baked cinnamon apples. Light bodied with a juicy mouthfeel. This beer is so light and refreshing despite its appearance and just gets drained in seconds. Could be an awesome session beer.

Pours dark reddish brown with a tan (and slightly pink?) head. Aroma is very intriguing. Grapes, dried apricots, Camembert cheese. Some roasty malts. Flavor is more bready and malty, with more of that cheesy tang in the finish. Strange mix of flavors, but I love it.
golden red brown with thin head and lots of bubbles.  Aroma is lactic, funky, yeast, brown sugar.  Initial complex taste fades quickly.  Smooth, bready, red fruits, and grass.
Pours deep red with a huge fluffy head. Aroma is caramel. Taste is dominated by caramel covered popcorn. Smooth beer with a dry, hoppy finish. Drinkable and enjoyable if a bit one dimensional.
Served on tap at AleSmith. Appearance is copper with a good amount of bubbles. The aroma and flavors are English style toasted malt with some caramel and nut notes.

Amber color with large white head. Aroma is  strong and lingers nicely in the nostrils with caramel/apple balanced well against the malt/hops. Very smooth on the first few sips with fruity tones in the finish and a slight bitter aftertaste.

Sampled at Lithys Septemberfest Tasting.  Clear dark amber with massive, fading off white head.  Nose of apple juice.  Flavor is a tart earthy sourness.  This must be old as hell.  Will have to try again fresh.
Pours a clear orange-amber with a thick two finger tan head, minor lacing. Aroma is grass, citrus and caramel. Flavor is a good balance, leaning a bit more to the malts, very smooth and drinkable

cloudy brown body with no head, sweet malt aroma with some mild roast, flavor is mostly sweet malts, there are some very mild hop flavors that are difficult to specifically pick out, what hops are there lightly spicy and noble in character, a very dry chalky roast finish, mild nut, hints of pine needles, light and refreshing and surprisingly complex flavors for a bitter,  This is a good example, Im surprised its not more bitter than it is, but Im glad to taste that AleSmith respects the ESB style.
gracias aleman.  excelente cerveza, son mas mi tipo.  mientras envasabamos la wheat y haciamos la bitter - excelente combinacion de trabajo recompensa!

The deep hazy chestnut brown head with luscious frothy and foamy head looks absolutely beautiful- but afterwards makes me think that something has gone awry.  Totally soured to taste and smell.  This bottle has been contaminated.  Unfortunately due to a blind taste test I didnt know and thought it was some kind of weird sour ale or something but it was pretty gross considering what it was supposed to be. I unfortunately consumed it all, and upon realizing- the notes I had seemed quite irrelevant.  It really looked pretty though.  Will have to re-rate soon
Bottle: Drank with rcasta while bottling the Wheat batch and brewing the Bitter. Malty flavors with slight bitterness, smooth. Food Pairing: Smoked Sausage.

Bottle.  Pours clear tawny with a large, frothy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (toasted grain, hay, meal), average hop (herbs), average yeast (dough, leather) with notes of pear, apple, and a hint of sugar.
